definition: A general increase in prices and fall in the purchasing value of money.
A period of economic decline usually marked by a fall in GDP and employment.
The total amount of a product or service available to consumers.
The desire and ability of consumers to purchase goods and services.
An economic system where private individuals own and operate businesses for profit.
An economic system where the means of production are owned and controlled by the state or the public.
The act of putting money into something to earn a profit.
The financial gain made from a business transaction.
When a business's expenses exceed its revenues.
A system or place where goods and services are bought and sold.
The exchange of goods and services between people or countries.
A tax on imported goods.
A government payment that supports a business or market.
A market structure where a single company dominates the supply of a product or service.
A plan for managing income and expenses.
Money collected by the government from individuals or businesses to fund public services.
Payment received by a worker for their services or labor.
The cost of borrowing money, usually expressed as a percentage.
The ability to borrow money or obtain goods with the promise to pay later.
Money owed to someone else.
